newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila pension says no plan to hike stock exposure.
newsitem.headline: Manila pension says no plan to hike stock exposure.

text.p: The Philippines' Social Security System (SSS) will not substantially increase its investment in local shares even if its amended charter allows a higher exposure, a high-ranking SSS official said on Friday.
"We're not going into the stock market with a big bang. We never feel that we're going to be a big player," senior deputy administrator Horacio Templo told Reuters.

The amended charter, which will take effect on May 24, allows SSS to invest in listed preferred and common shares to as high as 30 percent of its investment reserve fund, from the previous ceiling of only 10 percent.
Templo said the SSS would continue to invest heavily in fixed-rate government securities, which comprise slightly more than 50 percent of its investment portfolio.
About 40 percent were lent out to SSS members, he added.

The SSS, which is the pension fund of more than 20 million Filipino workers employed in the private sector, has assets worth about 100 billion pesos. The total amount of investible funds is not immediately available.
